articles.title: New 3D scan reveals a hidden network of moai carvers on Easter Island
articles.summary: A high-resolution 3D model of Rano Raraku shows that the moai were created in many distinct carving zones. Instead of a top-down system, the statues appear to have been produced by separate family groups working independently while sharing techniques. Evidence of varied carving styles and multiple transport routes supports this decentralized picture. The results challenge old assumptions about how large-scale monument building worked on Rapa Nui.
articles.content:
A new study published November 26, 2025 in the open-access journal PLOS One reports that the well-known stone figures of Rapa Nui (Easter Island) were created by many separate carving groups. The research team, led by Carl Philipp Lipo of Binghamton University, New York and colleagues, examined how these communities contributed to the making of the island's famous monuments.

Rapa Nui is widely recognized for its hundreds of stone statues (moai), crafted by Polynesian settlers beginning in the 13th century. Archaeological work has repeatedly shown that the island was home to many small family groups rather than a unified political system. This background has prompted researchers to explore whether the carving of moai followed the same decentralized structure.

High-Resolution 3D Modeling Reveals 30 Quarry Work Zones

For this study, scientists gathered more than 11,000 photographs of Rano Raraku, the primary moai quarry. These images were merged into a detailed 3D reconstruction that captured hundreds of moai preserved in different stages of production. After analyzing the model, the team identified 30 distinct quarrying areas, each showing unique carving approaches. Additional clues indicate that completed or partially shaped moai were moved away from the quarry along several different paths. Taken together, these patterns suggest that statue creation reflected the island's broader social organization, with carving efforts carried out independently rather than through centralized oversight.

New Evidence Challenges Long-Held Assumptions

The findings call into question the idea that projects of this scale require strict hierarchy or a single coordinating authority. Similarities between moai appear to come from the sharing of cultural knowledge instead of coordinated, joint labor. The new quarry model also provides a valuable dataset that can support future investigations and guide cultural management at this UNESCO World Heritage site. The same methods used here can also be applied to study other archaeological locations.

The authors explain: "Much of the so-called "mystery" of Rapa Nui (Easter Island) comes from the lack of openly available, detailed evidence that would allow researchers to evaluate hypotheses and construct explanations. Here, we present the first high-resolution 3D model of the moai quarry at Rano Raraku, the central quarry for nearly 1,000 statues, offering new insights into the organizational and manufacturing processes of these giant megalithic figures."

Fieldwork for this research was supported by a National Science Foundation grant (Award #2218602). The funders had no involvement in study design, data collection and analysis, decisions related to publication, or manuscript preparation.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant archaeological discovery using advanced 3D modeling technology that provides new insights into the social organization and monument-building practices of Easter Island. This research challenges long-held assumptions about centralized control in large-scale cultural projects and offers a valuable dataset for future studies and cultural preservation. The impact is broad for historical and cultural understanding and heritage management, benefiting society's knowledge of human history.
articles.personality_title: 3D scan reveals how separate groups carved Easter Island statues
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Easter Island, also called Rapa Nui, is famous for its large stone statues called moai. These statues were carved by Polynesian settlers starting in the 13th century. Until now, many people believed the statues were made under a single, organized system.

**What happened** – Researchers used over 11,000 photos to create a detailed 3D model of Rano Raraku, the main quarry where the moai were carved. They found 30 different carving zones, each with its own style. This shows that many separate family groups worked independently but shared carving techniques. They also discovered multiple paths used to move the statues away from the quarry.

**Impact** – This finding changes how we understand the statue-making process on Easter Island. Instead of a top-down system, the work was done by many small groups working on their own. This matches what we know about the island’s social groups and shows large projects can happen without central control. The 3D model also helps protect the site and can be used for future research.

**What’s next step** – Scientists plan to use this 3D modeling method to study other ancient sites. The detailed data will help archaeologists learn more about how past communities worked and support efforts to preserve important cultural places like Easter Island.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new 3D model reveals that Easter Island’s famous statues were carved by many independent groups, not a single organized system, changing how we understand their creation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un scan 3D révèle comment des groupes séparés ont sculpté les statues de l'île de Pâques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'île de Pâques, ou Rapa Nui, est célèbre pour ses grandes statues de pierre appelées moai. Ces statues ont été sculptées par des Polynésiens à partir du 13e siècle. Jusqu'à présent, on pensait que les statues étaient réalisées sous un système unique et organisé.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont utilisé plus de 11 000 photos pour créer un modèle 3D détaillé de Rano Raraku, la carrière principale où les moai ont été sculptés. Ils ont identifié 30 zones de taille différentes, chacune avec son propre style. Cela montre que plusieurs groupes familiaux travaillaient indépendamment tout en partageant les techniques. Ils ont aussi découvert plusieurs chemins utilisés pour déplacer les statues.

**Impact** – Cette découverte change notre compréhension du processus de création des statues sur l'île de Pâques. Au lieu d'un système centralisé, le travail était réalisé par de nombreux petits groupes indépendants. Cela correspond à ce que l'on sait des groupes sociaux de l'île et montre que de grands projets peuvent être faits sans contrôle central. Le modèle 3D aide aussi à protéger le site et pourra servir pour de futures recherches.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques comptent utiliser cette méthode de modélisation 3D pour étudier d'autres sites anciens. Les données détaillées aideront les archéologues à mieux comprendre le travail des communautés passées et à préserver les lieux culturels importants comme l'île de Pâques.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Un nouveau modèle 3D montre que les célèbres statues de l'île de Pâques ont été sculptées par plusieurs groupes indépendants, et non par un système unique, changeant ainsi notre compréhension de leur création.
articles.personality_title_es: Escaneo 3D muestra cómo grupos separados tallaron las estatuas de Isla de Pascua
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Isla de Pascua, también llamada Rapa Nui, es famosa por sus grandes estatuas de piedra llamadas moai. Estas estatuas fueron talladas por colonos polinesios desde el siglo XIII. Hasta ahora, se pensaba que las estatuas se hicieron bajo un solo sistema organizado.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores usaron más de 11,000 fotos para crear un modelo 3D detallado de Rano Raraku, la cantera principal donde se tallaron los moai. Encontraron 30 zonas de talla diferentes, cada una con su propio estilo. Esto muestra que muchos grupos familiares trabajaron de forma independiente pero compartieron técnicas. También descubrieron varios caminos usados para mover las estatuas fuera de la cantera.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo cambia la forma en que entendemos el proceso de creación de las estatuas en Isla de Pascua. En lugar de un sistema centralizado, el trabajo fue realizado por muchos grupos pequeños e independientes. Esto coincide con lo que sabemos sobre los grupos sociales de la isla y muestra que grandes proyectos pueden hacerse sin control central. El modelo 3D también ayuda a proteger el sitio y puede usarse en futuras investigaciones.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean usar este método de modelado 3D para estudiar otros sitios antiguos. Los datos detallados ayudarán a los arqueólogos a aprender más sobre cómo trabajaban las comunidades antiguas y apoyarán la preservación de lugares culturales importantes como Isla de Pascua.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un nuevo modelo 3D revela que las famosas estatuas de Isla de Pascua fueron talladas por muchos grupos independientes, no por un sistema organizado único, cambiando nuestra comprensión de su creación.
